titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Reece Marshall Newport Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Janet Elaine Gertz

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 07:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers contain two manuscripts. The first, "Plan for Raising Funds for Polish Relief", describes Newport's efforts to raise money for the Polish Relief Fund in 1940. The second, "The Saga of Pelorus Jack", is an unpublished fictional biography of a dolphin who reputedly escorted ships through Frenchmen's Strait in New Zealand in the 1880s and 1890s. Included is an incomplete manuscript, notes on dolphins and historical events related to the story, and correspondence, mostly with Carl C. Cutter

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The entire collection is available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 273 instead of the originals.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Reece Marshall Newport Papers (MS 373). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Reece M. Newport papers contains two manuscripts by Reece Marshall Newport. The first describes Newport's two-fold plan to raise money for the Polish Relief Fund in 1940 by reprinting the historical novel Thaddeus of Warsawby Jane Porter with a new foreword by Jan Paderewski and endorsements by other dignitaries, and by making a film of the life of General Thaddeus Kosciusko based on the novel.

The second manuscript, entitled "The saga of Pelorus Jack," is a fictional biography of the famous dolphin that reputedly escorted ships through Frenchmen's Strait in New Zealand in the 1880's and 1890's. Included in the papers are the incomplete manuscript, a small amount of correspondence concerning it (1941 â€“ 1949), mostly with Carl C. Cutter of the Mystic, Connecticut, Marine Museum and also notes by Newport on dolphins, New Zealand, Polynesia, oceanography, historical events bearing on the story and other related topics.
The papers were given to Yale University by Edward Randall in 1959.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Reece Marshall Newport, d 1957. Yale Class of 1901.
President of R.M. Newport & Company, Inc., real estate, mortgage loans and insurance, 404 Pioneer Building, St. Paul, Minnesota. Residence, 833 Grand Avenue, St. Paul, Minnesota.

He did not return to college for Senior Year becaue of financial difficulties and began working as a clerk in the auditor's office of the Northern Pacific Railway until JUne 1, 1901. Then he began working as a cleark in his fathers office in charge of real estate, insurance, and mortage loans, 1901-1912; after his father's death in 1912 the company was incorporated under the name R.M. Newport & Co.; its specialty was railroad and trackage property, general city real estate, mortage loans, and insurance.
The company's speciality is railroad and trackage property, and in addition thereto we do a general city real estate, mortgage loan, and insurance business at St. Paul.

He was a Republican and has been a member of the Seventh Ward Republican Committee, vice-chairman of the City and the Council Republican Organisation, and has been on the Republican City Campaign Committee for several years.

His connection with various organisations follows: member of St. Paul Athletic, Loyal Legion, Yale, and Alpha Delta Phi Clubs of New York; Town and Country Club, house committee; St. Paul German, chariman of the executive committee; one of the founders and a governor of the University Club; lieutenant, captain and director of the Minnesota Boat Club; secretary and treasurer of the Yale Alumni Association of the Northwest; president of the Aero Club of Minnesota.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners.
